abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tajikistan Second
            Poverty Alleviation Project were as follows: outcomes for
            the first project were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satsifactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) social funds continue to be relevant as
            instruments for maximizing the development impact through
            reaching remote communities which are underserved by
            government institutions and the NGO sector for different
            reasons as lack of capacity or difficult outreach,
            especially in post-conflict situations when different donors
            provide resources requiring community level needs assessment
            and participation in all stages of the projects cycle; 2)
            the community social infrastructure investments cannot be
            sustainable, especially in the long run if they are not
            incorporated a priori in local government development
            strategies and coordinated with line ministries; 3)
            maximizing the developmental impact requires that the social
            fund type of interventions are integrated well in the
            government policy making process; and 4) maximizing the
            developmental impact requires that interventions align
            capital investments with capacity building, testing,
            documenting and disseminating innovative good
            practices,analysis and knowledge sharing.
